revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
[[File:Joint blog close PS-0774.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama|Obama]] delivering his speech on health care to the [[United States Congress]]]] [[United States]] [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] discussed his plan for [[Health care reform in the United States|health care reform]] in a speech delivered to a joint session of the [[111th United States Congress]] on September 9, 2009 at 8:00 PM (EDT). The speech was delivered to Congress on the floor of the chamber of the [[United States House of Representatives]] in the [[United States Capitol]]. [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|House Speaker]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] presided over the joint session and was accompanied by the [[President of the United States Senate]], [[Joe Biden]], the [[Vice President of the United States]]. Energy Secretary [[Steven Chu]] was chosen as the [[designated survivor]] and did not attend the speech.{{cite news |title=Energy secretary stays away during Obama health care speech to joint session of Congress |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/politics/sns-ap-us-health-care-chu,0,7791126.story |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Chicago Tribune |date=2009-09-09 |accessdate=2009-09-14}} ==Speech== [[File:Obama Health Care Speech to Joint Session of Congress.jpg|thumb|300px|Obama addresses a [[Joint session of the United States Congress|joint session]] of [[United States Congress|Congress]]]]Obama's speech addressed topics regarding the [[public health insurance option]], private insurance reform, estimated costs and revenue, basic coverage for individuals and employers, as well as subsidies and waivers for those who can't afford coverage, and the importance of [[tort reform]] in bringing costs down.{{cite news |first=Victoria |last=Colliver |title=Outline and analysis of Obama's proposals |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/09/09/MNJO19KPTV.DTL |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |publisher=Hearst Communications Inc. |date=2009-09-10 |accessdate=2009-09-10}} The President's speech lasted 47 minutes{{cite news |first=Sheryl Gay |last=Stolberg |author2=Zeleny, Jeff |title=Obama, Armed With Details, Says Health Plan Is Necessary |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/10/us/politics/10obama.html?hp |publisher=New York Times |date=2009-09-09 |accessdate=2009-09-10}} and contained 5,614 words.{{cite news |title=Obama woos Congress on healthcare |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8247207.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-09-10 |accessdate=2009-09-10| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090909234449/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8247207.stm| archivedate= 9 September 2009 | deadurl= no}} It was briefly interrupted by a cry of "You lie!" from Republican Rep. [[Joe Wilson (U.S. politician)|Joe Wilson]], referring to a statement by Obama that his plan would not apply to illegal immigrants (discussed in more detail in [[#Outburst by Joe Wilson|the next section]]). Obama quoted a letter sent to him from [[Ted Kennedy]], who had died a few weeks earlier. Kennedy had composed the letter after he was diagnosed with terminal brain cancer, and requested that the letter be sent after he died. Quoting Kennedy's letter, Obama said, "that what we face is above all a moral issue; that at stake are not just the details of policy, but fundamental principles of social justice and the character of our country."{{cite web |last=Kennedy |first=Edward M. |authorlink=Ted Kennedy |title=Text of letter to the President from Senator Edward M. Kennedy |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Text-of-letter-to-the-President-from-Senator-Edward-M-Kennedy/ |date=2009-05-12 |work= |publisher=[[White House Press Secretary]] |accessdate=2009-09-10| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090910065606/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Text-of-letter-to-the-President-from-Senator-Edward-M-Kennedy/| archivedate= 10 September 2009 | deadurl= no}} In the quoted portions of his letter, Kennedy, a steadfast proponent of health care reform, also posed the question of what would happen if one knew treatment existed for a condition but one could not afford it.[http://www.khabrein.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26048&Itemid=57&limit=1&limitstart=5 Presidential address to Congress Full text of President Obama health care speech] President Obama placed health care reform into a broader historical perspective, in which the nature and role of government has been the subject of historical debate, and compared his reform to [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] and [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]]. He concluded his address by returning to Kennedy's theme of the "character of our country":
I understand how difficult this health care debate has been. I know that many in this country are deeply skeptical that government is looking out for them. I understand that the politically safe move would be to kick the can further down the road - to defer reform one more year, or one more election, or one more term. But that's not what the moment calls for. That's not what we came here to do. We did not come to fear the future. We came here to shape it. I still believe we can act even when it's hard. I still believe we can replace acrimony with civility, and gridlock with progress. I still believe we can do great things, and that here and now we will meet history's test. Because that is who we are. That is our calling. That is our character.
==Reactions== ===Outburst by Joe Wilson=== {{main|Joe Wilson (American politician)#"You Lie!" Outburst during 2009 Presidential address}} [[File:Joe Wilson's You Lie interruption.theora.ogv|thumb|left|Wilson's interruption of President Obama's address (at 00:15)]] {{wikisource|Raising a Question of the Privileges of the House}} During the speech, the president discussed the health coverage of illegal immigrants, saying: "There are also those who claim that our reform efforts would insure illegal immigrants. This, too, is false. The reforms I'm proposing would not apply to those who are here illegally." At this point, South Carolina Republican Rep. [[Joe Wilson (U.S. politician)|Joe Wilson]] yelled "You lie!", briefly interrupting the speech.{{cite video |people=Barack Obama, Joe Wilson |date=2009-09-09 |title= Obama Heckled by GOP During Speech to Congress |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3aE_nEoE5kE |format= YouTube |publisher = Associated Press |quote= The nastiness of August reached from the town halls into the Capitol as President Barack Obama spoke about his health care plan. South Carolina Republican Rep. Joe Wilson shouted "You lie!" after Obama talked about illegal immigrants. (Sept. 9) }} Wilson later issued a statement apologizing for his outburst.{{cite news|title=Obama heckled by GOP during speech to Congress |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gTWB1M9VPOte4M77spW7Z62NsGyQD9AK4ULO0 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=[[WebCite]] |accessdate=2009-09-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jjOQDczj?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gTWB1M9VPOte4M77spW7Z62NsGyQD9AK4ULO0 |archivedate=September 12, 2009 |df= }}{{cite news |first=Carl |last=Hulse |title=In Lawmaker’s Outburst, a Rare Breach of Protocol |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/10/us/politics/10assess.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=2009-09-09 |accessdate=2009-09-09}} On September 15, the House approved a "resolution of disapproval" (a [[List of United States Representatives expelled, censured, or reprimanded|reprimand]] as opposed to formal [[censure]]) against Wilson, on a near party-line 240-179 vote.{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Isenstadt |authorlink= |title=House passes resolution of disapproval |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0909/27194.html |newspaper=Politico |publisher= |date=15 September 2009 |accessdate=15 September 2009}} The outburst led to media coverage about the issue. Various sources noted that [[America's Affordable Health Choices Act|the House bill]] denies direct benefits, such as affordability credits, to illegal immigrants.{{cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2009/09/obamas-health-care-speech/ |title=Obama’s Health Care Speech |publisher=FactCheck.org |date= |accessdate=2009-09-16| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090917023027/http://www.factcheck.org/2009/09/obamas-health-care-speech/| archivedate= 17 September 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2009/08/seven-falsehoods-about-health-care/ |title=Seven Falsehoods About Health Care |publisher=FactCheck.org |date= |accessdate=2009-09-11| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090910043250/http://www.factcheck.org/2009/08/seven-falsehoods-about-health-care/| archivedate= 10 September 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web |author= |authorlink= |title=Joe Wilson of South Carolina said Obama lied, but he didn't |url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2009/sep/09/joe-wilson/joe-wilson-south-carolina-said-obama-lied-he-didnt/ |date=2009-09-09 |work=PolitiFact.com |publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |accessdate=2009-09-10}}{{cite web|url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2009/09/from-the-fact-check-desk-illegal-immigrants-and-health-care-reform.html |title=From the Fact Check Desk: Illegal Immigrants and Health Care Reform - Political Punch |publisher=Blogs.abcnews.com |accessdate=2009-09-11}} Section 246 of the bill, titled "NO FEDERAL PAYMENT FOR UNDOCUMENTED ALIENS," states: "Nothing in this subtitle shall allow Federal payments for affordability credits on behalf of individuals who are not lawfully present in the United States."{{cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/08/27/cnn-truth-squad-will-health-bill-pay-for-illegal-immigrants-an-update/ |title=CNN Political Ticker: All politics, all the time Blog Archive - CNN Truth Squad: Will health bill pay for illegal immigrants? An update « - Blogs from CNN.com |publisher=Politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com |date=2009-08-27 |accessdate=2009-09-16}} The bill did, however, require some to purchase health insurance who were not explicitly restricted from the proposed Health Insurance Exchange.{{cite web |title=Republicans Cite Report To Support Illegal Alien Health Care Charge |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2009/09/republicans_cite_report_to_sup.html |date=2009-09-10 |work=[[National Public Radio]] |accessdate=2009-09-10}} The Obama administration later stated that, in the final bill, these people would not be able to participate in the Exchange.{{cite news|url=http://prescriptions.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/11/illegal-immigrants-could-not-buy-insurance-on-new-exchange-white-house-says/ |title=Illegal Immigrants Could Not Buy Insurance on New ‘Exchange,’ White House Says |date=2009-09-11 |accessdate=2009-09-12 |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |author=Herszenhorn, David M. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915183311/http://prescriptions.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/11/illegal-immigrants-could-not-buy-insurance-on-new-exchange-white-house-says/ |archivedate=15 September 2009 |deadurl=no }} Specific language was subsequently included when the Senate healthcare-reform plan was introduced on September 16 which prohibits participation in the insurance exchange by persons not lawfully present in the U.S.{{cite web|url=http://health.yahoo.com/news/ap/us_health_care_overhaul.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091223021927/http://health.yahoo.com/news/ap/us_health_care_overhaul.html |archivedate=2009-12-23 }}{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/09/16/health.care.key.points/ | work=CNN | title=What's in Baucus' health care proposal? - CNN.com | accessdate=2010-04-26 | date=2009-09-16}} ===Republican response=== The official, post-speech Republican response was given by Congressman [[Charles Boustany]] of [[Louisiana]],{{cite web | author=Minority leader of the United States House of Representatives |authorlink=Minority leader of the United States House of Representatives |title=Rep. Boustany Delivers Republican Health Care Address |url=http://republicanleader.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=144009 |date=2009-09-09 |work= |publisher=[[John Boehner|Office of the House Republican Leader]] |accessdate=2009-09-10| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090910082928/http://republicanleader.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=144009| archivedate= 10 September 2009 | deadurl= no}} a former [[cardiothoracic surgery|cardiothoracic surgeon]].{{cite web | last=Boustany |first=Charles |authorlink=Charles Boustany |title=Boustany to Deliver National Republican Health Care Address following the President's Remarks to a Joint Session of Congress |url=http://boustany.house.gov/index.cfm?sectionid=49§iontree=23,24,49&itemid=436 |date=2009-09-08 |work=Latest News |publisher=[[United States House of Representatives]] |accessdate=2009-09-10| quote=Boustany, a cardiothoracic surgeon with more than 20 years of experience, was first elected to Congress in December 2004.}} With few notable exceptions, Congressional Republicans were silent as their Democratic colleagues applauded various points Obama made during the course of the speech.[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/6610886.html Lawmakers react along party lines to Obama remarks]. Retrieved September 9, 2009. Republicans also held up copies of the health care bills in objection when Obama spoke and others laughed when Obama said that there are "significant details" to be worked out before a health overhaul can be passed.[http://thedailyvoice.com/voice/2009/09/south-carolina-rep-joe-wilson-002258.php The Daily Voice: "South Carolina Rep. Joe Wilson calls the President a liar during speech"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913123238/http://thedailyvoice.com/voice/2009/09/south-carolina-rep-joe-wilson-002258.php |date=2009-09-13 }}. Retrieved September 9, 2009. ===Critical reception=== [[BBC News]] called Obama's health care speech "one of the most important speeches of his presidency." ''[[The Economist]]'' called the speech a "success on several measures".{{cite news |title=Fired up and ready to go |url=http://www.economist.com/world/unitedstates/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14419387 |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |publisher=The Economist Newspaper Limited |date=2009-09-10 |accessdate=2009-09-10}} Calling it a triumph of [[speech writing]] ''[[TIME|Time]]'' magazine praised the speech for its clarity, brevity and limited use of jargon.{{cite news |first=Joe |last=Klein |authorlink=Joe Klein |title=Obama's Appeal: A Test of National Character |url=http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,1921451,00.html |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |publisher= Time Inc. |date=2009-09-10 |accessdate=2009-09-11}} Other media outlets felt the speech was "too little, too late" to make a difference in the outcome of the health care debate.http://www.salon.com/opinion/paglia/2009/09/09/healthcare/{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/09/AR2009090903464.html | work=The Washington Post | title=With Health-Care Reform on the Line, Obama Reframes Critical Debate | first=Dan | last=Balz | date=2009-09-10 | accessdate=2010-04-26}} ===Financial markets=== The shares of health insurance companies advanced after analysts concluded that the proposal outlined by Obama as good news for healthcare investors.[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/health-insurers-shares-rise-after-obamas-speech-2009-09-10 Health insurers' shares rise after Obama's speech], [[MarketWatch]], 2009-09-10 [[Citigroup|Citi]] analyst Charles Boorady was quoted as saying that he expected shares to rise further as passage of health care reform would expand enrollment in plans.[http://money.cnn.com/news/newsfeeds/articles/djf500/200909101421DOWJONESDJONLINE000654_FORTUNE5.htm Health Insurer Stocks Rise Despite Obama's Call For Change] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915214055/http://money.cnn.com/news/newsfeeds/articles/djf500/200909101421DOWJONESDJONLINE000654_FORTUNE5.htm |date=September 15, 2009 }}, [[CNNMoney.com]], 2009-09-10 ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{wikisourcepar|Barack Obama's Health Care Speech}} *[https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/remarks-president-a-joint-session-congress-health-care Full text of speech] at [[Whitehouse.gov]] *[https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2009/09/10/us/politics/20090910-obama-health.html Video] at ''[[The New York Times]]'' * {{Unreferenced|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} '''Biopharm Australia''' is an [[Australia]]n [[Pharmaceutical industry|pharmaceutical company]]. Founded in the 1980s, Biopharm Australia develops sulfated [[polysaccharide]]s for use in [[veterinary medicine]] and has ongoing research and development commitments in [[osteoarthritis]], [[musculoskeletal diseases]] and [[cancer]].
Biopharm Australia pioneered the veterinary development of sodium pentosan polysulfate as a disease modifying osteoarthritis drug (DMOAD) under the brand [[Cartrophen]]. The company invests heavily in the research and development of medicines that improve animal quality of life and strengthen the human-animal bond.
==History== Biopharm Australia was incorporated in 1987 in Sydney, Australia. It was established to advance healthy treatments for osteoarthritis. Biopharm Australia aim to improve animal health through the development and use of the best technology. Cartrophen Vet is a sodium pentosan polysulfate for the treatment of osteoarthritis (OA) also known as the degenerative joint disease.
In the late 1980s Biopharm Australia began collaborating on osteoarthritis treatments. It was registered under licence in Australia as Anarthron. In 1989 Cartrophen Vet was registered in Australia and New Zealand in 1989, Biopharm Australia achieved registrations in the 1990s in Europe and North America including United Kingdom, Ireland, Finland and Canada.
In the 2000s Cartrophen Vet was registered in Austria*, Belgium*, Denmark, Germany, France*, the Netherlands*, Sweden and Japan. The horse equivalent product Cartrophen Equine Forte was registered in New Zealand and the United Arab Emirates.
In the early 2010s Cartrophen Equine Forte was registered in Australia. At the same time Biopharm’s product Cartrophen Vet achieved registrations in Poland, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland*, Argentina and Chile.
===Registrations Cartrophen Vet=== 2017: Cartrophen Vet is registered in 20 countries including Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom, Ireland, Finland, Canada, Austria*, Belgium*, Denmark, Germany, France*, the Netherlands*, Sweden, Japan, Poland, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland*, Brazil, Argentina and Chile
===Registrations Cartrophen Equine Forte=== 2014: Cartrophen Equine Forte is registered in Australia, New Zealand and the United Arab Emirates.
[*Cartrophen Vet is registered as Anarthron in these countries]
==Products== Cartrophen products are for the treatment of non-infectious inflammatory joint disease in dogs and horses. Biopharm's testing laboratories are licensed by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA). The TGA is the official inspection service for veterinary products. The TGA is internationally recognized under mutual recognition agreement e.g. with the EEC.
===Cartrophen Vet (for dogs and horses)=== Cartrophen Vet is approved for use in dogs in all countries where registered and is also approved for use in horses only in Australia, New Zealand, Argentina and Chile. It contains 100 mg/mL sodium pentosan polysulfate.
===Cartrophen Equine Forte (for horses)=== It contains 250 mg/mL of sodium pentosan polysulafte and is approved in Australia, New Zealand and the United Arab Emirates.
==References==
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.cartrophen.com}}

'''The Canadian Association of Gastroenterology''' (CAG) was founded in 1962 to promote the [[Research|study]] of the [[Gastrointestinal tract|digestive tract]] in [[Health care|health]] and [[disease]]. The Association is built on broad principles and includes individuals of different disciplines ([[Physician|physicians]], [[Surgeon|surgeons]], [[Pediatrics|paediatricians]], [[Radiology|radiologists]], [[Scientist|basic scientists]]). Today, the Association comprises more than 1,100 members. CAG members are actively involved in research, education and patient care in all areas of digestive health and disease, contributing to the [[Economics|economic]] and social health of all Canadians. The [[Canadian Digestive Health Foundation]] is the [[Foundation (nonprofit)|foundation]] of the CAG.
==External links== *[http://www.cag-acg.org/ Canadian Association of Gastroenterology web site]

revision.text:
[[Image:Sri Lankan Passport.jpg|thumb|[[Sri Lankan passport]] — a document issued to persons with Sri Lankan citizenship.]] Issues and practices related to '''childbirth in Sri Lanka''' are influenced by the sociocultural composition, political history and violence within the country.
==Background== [[Image:Sri Lanka-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|The island-nation of [[Sri Lanka]].]] {{main|Sri Lanka}}
===Physical environment=== {{main|Geography of Sri Lanka}} [[Sri Lanka]] is a small island nation in the [[Indian Ocean]], off the southeast coast of [[India]]. The island is characterized by a [[tropical monsoon climate]] that is divided into the northeast monsoon (December to March) and southwest monsoon (June to October).<ref name=CIA2011> {{cite web |title = World Fact Book: Sri Lanka |publisher = [[Central Intelligence Agency]] |year=2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011 |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ce.html }}</ref> The terrain is mostly low, flat to rolling fertile plains. Highlands with deep valleys exist in the central-southern interior of the country.<ref name=CIA2011/> Nearly one-third of Sri Lanka's total land mass is covered by natural vegetation, however much of it has been depleted due to intensive agricultural practices.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sri Lanka - Plant and animal life {{!}} history - geography|url = http://www.britannica.com/place/Sri-Lanka/Plant-and-animal-life|website = Encyclopædia Britannica|access-date = 2016-02-19}}</ref>
===History=== {{main|History of Sri Lanka}} The [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]], who likely migrated from southern India, are first people known to inhabit [[Sri Lanka]].<ref name=DeSilva1981> {{cite book | last=De Silva | first=K.M. | title=A history of Sri Lanka | publisher=C. Hurst and Co. Ltd. | place=London, U.K | year=1981 }}</ref> It is commonly believed that they arrived in the 5th century BC.<ref name=DeSilva1981/> Near 300 BC, there is evidence that [[Tamil people|Tamil]] people began to migrate from Southern India to the island now known as Sri Lanka.<ref name=DeSilva1981/> The [[Portugal|Portuguese]] discovered the island largely by accident in 1505 CE and established their first trading settlement in 1517.<ref name=DeSilva1981/> The [[Portugal|Portuguese]] briefly controlled the coastal areas of the island, followed by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] in the 17th century. With these colonizers came the introduction of [[Roman Catholic]] missionaries who sought to convert Sinhalese and Tamil people to [[Catholicism]].<ref name=DeSilva1981/> By March 1815, the island was formally united under [[United Kingdom|British]] rule <ref name=DeSilva1981/> Throughout the 19th century, the British brought Tamil workers from Southern India to staff the growing number of [[rubber]] and [[tea]] plantations.<ref name=U.S.2011> {{cite report |title= Background note: Sri Lanka |year = 2011 |publisher= U.S. Department of State, Bureau of South and Central Asian Affairs |url= https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5249.htm }}</ref> The people of the island gained independence from the [[United Kingdom|British]] in 1948 and formed the nation of [[Ceylon]]. The official name was changed to [[Sri Lanka]] in 1972, when [[Buddhism]] was named the primary [[religion]] of the country.<ref name=DeSilva1981/>
Throughout the late 20th century and into the 21st century, Sri Lanka remained a country wrought with turmoil and war. Increasing Sinhalese nationalism led to disenfranchisement of the Tamil minority. Beginning in 1983 and lasting nearly three decades, brutally violent armed conflicts took place between the pro-independent militant Tamil group, named [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]] (LTTE), and the Sinhalese dominant Sri Lankan government force.<ref name=UN2004> {{cite report |author= United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees |title= UNHCR Country Operations Plan 2003 - Sri Lanka |year = 2002 |url= http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/3d941f5e1c.html }}</ref> These years were characterized by civil unrest, violence, guerrilla attacks, acts of terrorism and conventional warfare. During the conflict, Northern and Eastern provinces served as primary battlefields. It is estimated that more than 60,000 people were killed in the conflict.<ref name=UN2004/> A [[ceasefire]] was signed in 2002, but mostly ignored and officially rejected by the Sri Lankan government in 2008. The Sri Lankan government declared victory over the LTTE in May 2009 with the death of rebel leader [[Velupillai Prabhakaran]].<ref name=Good2010>Goodhand, J. (2010). Stabilising a victor's peace? humanitarian action and reconstruction in eastern Sri Lanka. Disasters, 34, S342-S367. {{doi|10.1111/j.1467-7717.2010.01212.x}}</ref>
===Religion=== {{Main|Religion in Sri Lanka}} Religion is a vibrant part of Sri Lankan culture. The predominant religions are [[Buddhism]], [[Hindu]], [[Muslim]] and [[Christianity]].<ref name=CIA2011/> [[Buddhism]] was introduced sometime between 250-210 BC,<ref name=DeSilva1981/> and became the official religion of Sri Lanka in 1972. The 1978 constitution grants primacy to Buddhism, while also ensuring freedom of religion for all citizens. Throughout Sri Lanka's long history, Buddhism has remained an active part of the culture. Nearly 70% of the population is Buddhist.<ref name=CIA2011/> Due to the extensive conflict and war in the northern and eastern provinces, data regarding religious affiliation is variable. The national census states that 8% of the population identified as [[Muslim]], 7% as [[Hindu]], 6% as [[Christian]], and the remaining 10% were unspecified.<ref name=census2002>Department of Census and Statistics, in collaboration with Ministry of Health, Nutrition and Welfare. (2002). Sri Lanka demographic and health survey 2000. Pitakotte, Sri Lanka: State Printing Corporation</ref> The majority of Sri Lankan Muslims practice [[Sunni Islam]]. Sizable minorities of both Sinhalese and Tamils identify as Christians, most of whom are Roman Catholic.<ref name=CIA2011/>
===Political system=== {{Main|Government of Sri Lanka}} [[Image:Coat of arms of Sri Lanka.svg|thumb|[[Coat of arms of Sri Lanka]].]] Sri Lanka is governed within the framework of a presidential representative [[democratic republic]].<ref name=CIA2011/> In this multi-party system the [[president]] is the head of state, head of government and the commander of the armed forces. The long-standing conflict between the majority Sinhalese and the Tamil minority is apparent within the political structure. Both the president and prime minister are members of the socialist [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party]]. The party was founded in 1951, and generally represents the interests of the nationalist Sinhala parties. The primary opposition party is the conservative [[United National Party]]. In 1959, Sri Lanka was led by [[Sirimavo Bandaranaike]], the world's first female chief executive. [[Mahinda Rajapaksa]] became president in 2005 and was re-elected in January, 2010, two years before the end of his term.<ref name=U.S.2011/>
===Economic system=== {{Main|Economy of Sri Lanka}}
Sri Lanka's [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) per capita is $4,900 USD <ref name=CIA2011/> with an annual growth rate estimated at 8%.<ref name=U.S.2011/> The average annual income is $964 USD <ref name=Kaiser>Kaiser Family Foundation, Global Health Facts. (2010). Country Data Source: Sri Lanka. Retrieved from http://www.globalhealthfacts.org/country.jsp?c=199</ref> and about 6% of the population lives below $1 USD per day.<ref name=Kaiser/> In 2001, the country faced bankruptcy when national debt overtook GDP. Crisis was averted when the government gathered international loans after a ceasefire was signed with the LTTE.<ref name=CIA2011/>
In 2009, a third of Sri Lankans worked in agriculture, a fourth in industry and the remainder primarily worked in services jobs.<ref name=CIA2011/> Four percent of males are unemployed.<ref name=Kaiser/> Women are becoming increasingly active in the job market and female unemployment has dropped from 22% in 1993, to 8% in 2009.<ref name=CIA2011/> The primary economic sectors include tourism, textiles, clothing manufacture, agricultural products and exportation of tea, apparel, gemstones and rubber.<ref name=CIA2011/>
===Social structure and organization=== In Sri Lanka, there has not been a comprehensive national population census completed since 1981. The 2001 national census did not include vital information from conflict areas of the northern and eastern parts of the country. Due to the ongoing violence in Sri Lanka, most demographic data available is estimated based on 1981 or 2001 data, and variation exists among data sources. The [[CIA World Factbook]] lists Sri Lanka's current population as 20,653,913 persons.<ref name=CIA2011/> Considering the island is only {{convert|65,610|km2|sqmi|sp=us}}, it is a very densely populated nation. Over 85% of the population live in non-urban environments.<ref name=CIA2011/> The largest city is [[Colombo]], with a population of 1,819,777. Sri Lanka is occupied by several ethnic groups. The Sinhalese are the predominant ethnic group (74%), followed by [[Sri Lankan Tamils]] (13%), [[Indian Tamils of Sri Lanka|Indian Tamils]] (5%) and [[Moors]] (Muslim) (7%).<ref name=Rannan>Rannan-Eliya, R. P. and Sikurajapathy, L. (2008). Sri Lanka: "Good Practice" in Expanding Health Coverage. In World Bank (311-354)</ref> Sinhala is the national language and is the predominant language spoken by 74% of the population. Most Tamils and Moors speak Tamil, part of the South Indian linguistic group. Due to the extensive conflict between Sri Lankan government and Tamil separatists that took place in the late 20th and early 21st centuries, several hundred thousand Tamil citizens fled their homes in conflict zones and were placed in government run camps for internally displaced persons (IDPs), or sought refuge in other countries.<ref name=Foreign>Committee on Foreign Relations, United States Senate, One Hundred Eleventh Congress, First Session, December 7, 2009</ref> The total number of displaced persons is unknown, though in 1994 it was estimated over 500,000 people were displaced internally and more than 200,000 people fled internationally.<ref name=Chand>Chandrakanthan, A. J. V. (1994). An exodus sans destination: Refugees and the internally displaced in Sri Lanka. Paper presented at the 4th International Research and Advisory Panel Conference, University of Oxford, Oxford, England</ref>
Since 2009, considerable effort has been made to relocate the hundreds of thousand IDPs from government camps. When forced to flee conflict zones, most IDPs left behind their homes, assets, and tools necessary for their livelihoods.<ref name=Good2010/> The Sri Lankan government reported that rations were provided for families selected for resettlement from IDP camps. These rations included agricultural tool kits, dry rations, an initial payment of Rs. 5,000 (est. $44 USD), a shelter grant of Rs. 25,000 (est. $219 USD), roofing sheets, provision of rice seed, fertilizer and transportation.<ref name=Foreign/> Even in resettled communities, many people continue to face insecurity and poverty.<ref name=Good2010/><ref name=Amirthalingam>Amirthalingam, K. and Lakshman , R.W. (2009). Displaced livelihoods in Sri Lanka: an economic analysis. Journal of Refugee Studies, 22(4), 502-524. {{doi|10.1093/jrs/fep031}}</ref> As of February 2011, nearly 17,500 people continue to live at Menik Farm, Sri Lanka's largest camp for IDPs. Recent reports claim that the government hopes to resettle all conflict-displaced people by the end of 2011.<ref name=IRIN>Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN), Asia. (2011). Sri Lanka: displaced to be resettled by end 2011 Retrieved from http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportID=91888</ref> Rebuilding infrastructure in northern and eastern provinces affected by war is an ongoing task.<ref name=Good2010/><ref name=Amirthalingam/>
===Education=== {{Main|Education in Sri Lanka}} Sri Lanka's education system is state funded, and offered free of charge at all levels, including the university level. Schooling is compulsory for children from 5 to 13 years of age. The national literacy rate is 91%.<ref name=census2002/> The reported literacy rate of the urban population is 93%, 92% of the rural population and 75% of the estate population.<ref name=census2002/> The literacy rate among women is 89%.<ref name=CIA2011/> Nearly 70% of the population is educated beyond the 9th grade.<ref name=census2002/>
==Health Information== {{Main|Health in Sri Lanka}} Considering the low annual income and many years of internal conflict, Sri Lanka's health indicators are stronger than those of many other developing countries. According to the Kaiser Family Foundation's Global Health Database,<ref name=Kaiser/> 90% of Sri Lankans have access to water and 91% have access to sanitation. An estimated 2,800 people are living with HIV/AIDS, and 20,000 are living with tuberculosis. The life expectancy at birth is 74 years of age.<ref name=CIA2011/> Health services are provided to Sri Lankan citizens free of charge and over 93% of the population has access to basic health care. The national prevalence of anemia among school children is about 12%.<ref name=Pathmeswaran>Pathmeswaran, A., Jayatissa, R., Samarasinghe, S., Fernando, A., de Silva, R., Thattil, R., and de Silva, N. (2010). Health status of primary schoolchildren in Sri Lanka. Ceylon Medical Journal, 50(2), 46-50. {{doi|10.4038/cmj.v50i2.1567}}</ref> About one third of Sri Lankan children<ref>{{Cite web|title = UNICEF Sri Lanka - Our Focus Areas - Malnutrition|url = http://www.unicef.org/srilanka/activities_1667.htm|website = www.unicef.org|access-date = 2016-02-17}}</ref> are undernourished ([[Body Mass Index|BMI]]-for age below the 5th percentile for age and sex).<ref name=Pathmeswaran/> Children in the northern and eastern provinces have a much higher proportion of health problems when compared to children living in other provinces.<ref name=Pathmeswaran/>
Sri Lanka has an extensive network of health care institutions. The health system consists of both the state and private sector. State health services include preventative, curative and rehabilitative health services. Health services are organized and delivered through the Department of Health Services and the Provincial Health Sector. The Sri Lankan health system incorporates Western, [[Ayurvedic]] and [[Homeopathic]] medicine. The Ministry of Health oversees national health services.<ref name=Fernando2003>Fernando, D., Jayatilleka, A., and Karunaratna, V. (2003). Pregnancy—reducing maternal deaths and disability in Sri Lanka: National strategies. British Medical Bulletin, 67(1), 85-98. {{doi|10.1093/bmb/ldg008}}</ref> Eight Provincial Directors of Health Services are responsible for the management and implementation of health services within each province. These services include provincial, base, district and rural hospitals, maternity homes and outpatient facilities. Each province is divided into geographical areas, with a defined population, who are served by a Medical Officers of Health (MOH). Within each MOH area, a team of field level health workers, including Public Health Nurses (PHN), Public Health Inspector (PHI) and Public Health Midwives (PHM), work with a Medical Officer to deliver health care services at a community level. The PHM are responsible for delivering antenatal, natal and postnatal services in hospitals, community health centers and in patient's homes.<ref name=Fernando2003/> Several different types of health care facilities exist and patients may choose where they receive services.
Sri Lanka's achievements in maternal health and family planning are perceived as a success. In the 1930s, Sri Lanka's maternal mortality ratio (MMR) was 2,000 deaths per 100,000 live births.<ref name=Prata>Prata, N., Passano, P., Sreenivas, A. and Gerdts, C.E. (2010). Maternal mortality in developing countries: challenges in scaling-up priority interventions. Women’s Health, 6(2), 311-327. {{doi|10.2217/whe.10.8}}</ref> Recognizing this as a national problem, the government implemented programs to improve infrastructure, education, sanitation and health systems in poor and under-served areas. Simultaneously, there was an improvement in maternal health services and extensive training of, and improved community access to, Public Health Nurse-Midwives.<ref name=Prata/> Maternal care now encompasses antenatal care, intrapartum and postnatal care. These strategies enabled Sri Lanka to reduce the MMR by half every 6–12 years between 1930 and 1995.<ref name=Prata/> In 2002, the MMR was 43 per 100,000 live births.<ref name=Family>Family Health Bureau (2007). Annual Report on Family Health Sri Lanka, 2004-2005, Ministry of Health Sri Lanka Publication, Colombo, Sri Lanka</ref> The estimated total fertility rate is 2.2 births per woman and population growth rate is 0.93%.<ref name=CIA2011/> The infant mortality rate was 11.2 per 1000 live births in 2003.<ref name=Family/> The contraceptive prevalence rate was 70%; the infant mortality rate was 10.2 for female infants and 12.9 for male infants per 1,000 live births.<ref name=CIA2011/>
In 1927, the midwifery services in the Colombo municipality were re-organized to include training of all midwives working in the municipality.<ref name=Fernando2003/> Since then, PHM training has continued expand and follow a standardized course. By 1958, about 58% of the births were attended by a skilled birth attendant, of which 25% were deliveries in the home by a PHM.<ref name=Fernando2003/> Since the 1950s the number of institutional (maternity home or hospital) deliveries has continued to increase, and in 2001, 92% of all deliveries took place in institutions.<ref name=Fernando2003/>
===Effect of conflict on maternal health=== Many years of ethnic conflict have led to separation between the various ethnic and religious groups who inhabit Sri Lanka. Women in living in the conflict zones of northern and eastern Sri Lanka experience worse maternal outcomes compared to national averages.<ref name=WHO2002>World Health Organization (2002) Health system and health needs of the north-east Sri Lanka. Colombo, Sri Lanka: Vishva Lekha</ref> Research conducted in the areas found significantly higher levels of poverty in conflict zones. On a national level, the proportion of the population living in poverty was 22.7%, but in the district of Amapara, nearly 65% of the population was living in poverty in 2002.<ref name= Kottegoda>Kottegoda, S., Samuel, K., & Emmanuel, S. (2008). Reproductive health concerns in six conflict-affected areas of Sri Lanka. Reproductive Health Matters, 16(31), 75-82. {{doi|10.1016/S0968-8080(08)31359-7}}</ref>
Young people living in conflict areas have higher rates of school drop-out, marry earlier and become pregnant earlier than young people in other parts of the country.<ref name= Kottegoda/> Women in these areas face especially poor health outcomes These women are also subject to higher rates of domestic violence and many women report that their husbands force them to have sexual intercourse.<ref name= Kottegoda/> Women in these areas have reduced access to contraception, and this may increase pregnancies in conflict zones.<ref name= Kottegoda/> The total rate of fertility in conflict zones is 2.6 live births per woman <ref name=Fernando2003/> while the national average is 2.2 live births per woman.<ref name=CIA2011/>
Lack of basic health infrastructure combined with shortages of health professionals has severely limited reproductive health services in the northern and eastern provinces.<ref name= Kottegoda/> They have extremely limited access to emergency obstetric care, increased rates of maternal morbidity and mortality, and higher rates of low birth weight babies.<ref name= Kottegoda/> While the national rates of home birth are very low, one out of five women in conflict areas birth at home.<ref name= Kottegoda/> In some districts, such as Batticaloa, as many as 41% of women give birth at home.<ref name=Fernando2003/> Primary reasons for home births are: destruction of health centers, danger of travel, lack of transportation and poverty.<ref name= Kottegoda/> The national PHM program virtually eliminated traditional birth attendants in Sri Lanka, but when women are forced to birth at home they may have the assistance of a traditional medicine woman, known as ''Marauthuvivhvhi''.<ref name= Kottegoda/> These birth attendants use home remedies, such as powders, herbs, oils and an herbal drink called ''perunkayam'' to support the woman through birth.<ref name= Kottegoda/> These factors increase the risk involved with childbirth and highlight the needs of women living in the northern and eastern provinces of Sri Lanka.<ref name=WHO2002/>
==Marriage== Unlike other Asian countries, Sri Lankan women have had equal access to education for many years and men and women enjoy similar rates of literacy. In other countries women's increased access to education and increased presence in the workforce has delayed the age of marriage, but these factors are less influential in Sri Lanka.<ref name=Malhortra>Malhortra, A, and Tsui, A.O. (1996). Marriage timing in Sri Lanka: The role of modern norms and ideas. Journal of Marriage and the Family, 58, 476-490</ref> Typically, Sri Lankans marry later than people in other Asian countries. In 1961, the average age of marriage was 22 years old, and today the average age of marriage is 25 years old in Sri Lanka.<ref name=Malhortra/> Muslim women marry earlier than Sinhalese and Tamil women.<ref name=Malhortra/> School attendance is believed to delay the age of marriage because women in school are not considered adults and are not ready for marriage. Birth order also influences age of marriage. Women with unmarried older sisters tend to marry later because of the tradition that women should marry in their birth order.<ref name=Malhortra/> Women who have arranged marriages typically marry later than those who choose their own husbands.<ref name=Malhortra/>
==Infertility== [[Infertility]] is a deeply distressing issue among Sri Lankan couples. In the Sinhalese culture, birth is the sign of a successful marriage and rituals are performed if a woman does not conceive during the early years of marriage.<ref name=Paranavitana>Paranavitana, R. (2008). Some customs and superstitions associated with the childbirth in Sri Lankan Sinhalese society. Research Journal of Folkloristics, 1(1), 35-39</ref> Often the couple and family members will make vows at a religious shrine and seek blessings from monks to help with conception.<ref name=Paranavitana/> When a woman has a difficult time becoming pregnant, some people believe it is caused by misdeeds that took place in a previous lifetime.<ref name=Paranavitana/> Performing virtuous deeds in the present life can help neutralize these deeds. Examples of beneficial acts include giving money to monks, beggars or children in need, lighting lamps or bathing the foot of a sacred Bo-tree with water or milk.<ref name=Paranavitana/>
A cultural issue arises when considering sperm donation among Buddhists. While donation of blood or body products are considered virtuous giving of one's self, semen is a very different matter.<ref name=Simpson>Simpson, B. (2004). Impossible gifts: bodies, Buddhism and bioethics in contemporary Sri Lanka. Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute, 10(4), 839-859. {{doi|10.1111/j.1467-9655.2004.00214.x}}</ref> In Aruvedic medicine, semen is "considered the highest of substances" and "loss of such a powerful substance is widely held to have a number of consequences such as anxiety, mental impairment, and impotence.<ref name=Simpsonp553>Simpson, B. (2004). p. 553</ref> Some physicians expressed concerns about the risk of potential mix-ups of sperm in [[in-vitro fertilization]], fearing "children with such origins might experience a deep and troubling sense of strangeness towards a father who is not biologically related whilst expressing a desire to establish the genitor's real identity.".<ref name=Simpsonp553/> Because sperm donation involves ejaculation, which has origins in "physical pleasure for which there can be no justification in Buddhism," acquiring donor sperm is often a difficult task.<ref name=Simpsonp553/> Monetary incentives cannot be used because the purchase of human tissue, including gametes, is illegal <ref name=Simpson/>).
==Pregnancy== ===Ideas regarding pregnancy=== Even though the government has actively encouraged family planning, Sri Lankans still regard pregnancy as a blessing and birth is a symbol of a successful marriage.<ref name=Paranavitana/><ref name=Wanasundera>Wanasundera, N.P. (2002). Cultures of the world: Sri Lanka. New York: Marshall Cavendish Reference Books</ref> Pregnancy outside of marriage is very rare in Sri Lanka.<ref name=Malhortra/><ref name=Olsson>Olsson, P. and Wijewarena, K. (2010). Unmarried women’s decisions on pregnancy termination: Qualitative interviews in Colombo, Sri Lanka. Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare, 1, 135-141. {{doi|10.1016/j.srhc.1010.07.005}}</ref> Culturally it is important that a woman remains a virgin until marriage.<ref name=Olsson/> Single mothers do not receive government-based aid. Children born to unwed mothers are often labeled as illegitimate and considered outcasts in society.<ref name=Olsson/>
===Preparation for birth=== When husbands learn their wife is pregnant, they make a vow to perform the ''Ratrayakuma'' ritual.<ref name=Paranavitana/> This ritual, which involves hanging a pot containing coins, a betel leaf and flowers from the rafters, is done to appease the evil spirit Rata Yaka, who is believed to prevent successful child bearing and delivery.<ref name=Paranavitana/> During a first pregnancy, couples often visit temples of special significance in the Buddhist faith.<ref name=Paranavitana/> Examples of such temples are [[Temple of the Tooth]] in [[Kandy]] or the Sacred [[Bodhi tree]] at [[Anuradhapura]]. At the temple they pray for the pregnancy and ask for an uncomplicated birth and healthy life.<ref name=Paranavitana/> They make vows to ensure their wishes are granted. If their wishes are granted, they return to the temple or shrine to make offerings of praise to the Gods who protected their newborn child and mother during pregnancy and birth.<ref name=Paranavitana/>
During pregnancy, family members take care to please the pregnant mother and protect her, and her unborn child, by relieving her of household duties.<ref name=Paranavitana/> The pregnant woman's mother, grandmother or mother-in-law supervises meals. While pregnant, women may experience ''Doladuka'', or suffering of two hearts.<ref name=Paranavitana/> This experience includes unusual desires to eat particularly sour fruits or indulge in specific acts.<ref name=Paranavitana/> These wishes must be fulfilled to protect the fetus from physical or mental defects. Pregnant women avoid eating twinned foods as they are thought to lead to the birth of twins. Relatives and friends visit often to give gifts of fruits and boiled rice with curry wrapped in a banana leaf.<ref name=Paranavitana/> Traditionally, baby showers are considered bad luck and gifts are not given until after the birth of the child.<ref name=Wanasundera/> When preparing clothing for the new baby, care is taken to never complete the garment before the birth of the baby, as this assumes the birth is a certainty.<ref name=Paranavitana/>
In the last three months of pregnancy, it is typical for women move their parents’ home and stay a few weeks after the delivery to recover and receive care.<ref name=Paranavitana/><ref name=DeSilva1998>De Silva, W.I. (1998). Puerperal morbidity: A neglected area of maternal health in Sri Lanka. Biodemography and Social Biology, 45(3), 223-245</ref> This practice is especially common among first time mothers.<ref name=DeSilva1998/> During this time, Buddhist monks are invited to the home to chant blessings and expel evil spirits who might harm the woman and fetus.<ref name=Paranavitana/>
===Prenatal care=== The PHM provides prenatal care to women at home visits and in health clinics.<ref name=DeSilva1998/> These visits include blood pressure screening, measurement of weight and education related to nutritional needs during pregnancy.<ref name=DeSilva2001>De Silva, W.I. and Ban, D.J. (2001). Biomedical facts and social constructs: the relative attention paid to prenatal and postpartum periods in Sri Lanka. Asia-Pacific Population Journal, 16(2), 45-62</ref> A PHM registers all pregnant women, and most are registered in the first trimester of pregnancy.<ref name=Family/> Nearly every pregnant woman (98.5%) receives antenatal care.<ref name=Family/> According to Demographic and Health Survey 2000, 95% of women visited a clinic at least once during pregnancy and 84% had a midwife visit her home.<ref name=census2002/> Most women receive six or more home visits by the PHM during pregnancy.<ref name=Family/><ref name=DeSilva2001/> Only a very small percent of pregnant women receive fewer than three visits by a PHM.<ref name=DeSilva2001/> Women typically receive one visit during the first trimester, then two to three visits additional during each of the second and third trimesters.<ref name=DeSilva2001/>
===Extrinsic factors=== Currently little information exists regarding extrinsic factors that may affect pregnancy, such as air, water, food and drink. This is an area for additional research.
==Birth== ===Location and type of delivery=== Skilled [[birth attendant]]s attend more than 97% of births In Sri Lanka.<ref name=census2002/> Nearly all births (99%) take place in a hospital or maternity home and are assisted by a physician or PHM.<ref name=DeSilva1998/> All first pregnancies and high-risk pregnancies are referred to a health facility staffed by an obstetrician. Most women give birth vaginally, but the incidence of [[cesarean section]], or C-section, is rising. In 1986, the rate of C-section was 9% and by 1999, the rate rose to 14.4% of births in government hospitals.<ref name=Fernando1999>Fernando, L. and Abeywardena, M. (1999). Trends in caesarean section. Sri Lanka Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, 16, 14-20</ref> Currently, 66% of births are spontaneous vaginal deliveries, 4% are operative vaginal deliveries and 30% are by C-section.<ref name=Lumbiganon>Lumbiganon, P., Laopaiboon, M., Gülmezoglu, A. M., Souza, J. P., Taneepanichskul, S., Ruyan, P., …Villar, J. (2010). Method of delivery and pregnancy outcomes in Asia: The WHO global survey on maternal and perinatal health 2007–08. The Lancet, 375(9713), 490-499. {{doi|10.1016/S0140-6736(09)61870-5}}</ref> It is hypothesized that the increase in C-sections is due to a variety of factors, including increased use of epidural anesthesia and fetal monitoring.<ref name=Gunasekera>Gunasekera, P.C., Wijesinghe, P.S. and Goonewardene, I.M. (2001). The caesarean rate is rising</ref>
===Use of technology=== Little information is known about actual practices in Sri Lanka, but the Sri Lankan College of Obstetric Gynecology (SLCOG) publishes national guidelines for management of certain conditions of pregnancy.
===Uncomplicated labor=== SLCOG defines normal labor as "spontaneous onset, low-risk at the start and remaining low risk throughout the process".<ref name=SLCOGap1>Sri Lanka College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (SLCOG). (2010). National guidelines: Management of uncomplicated labor. p.1. Retrieved from http://www.gfmer.ch/SRH-Course-2010/national-guidelines/pdf/Management-Uncomplicated-Labour-SLCOG.pdf</ref> Normal labor results in a birth between 37 and 42 weeks gestation and the fetus is delivered from a vertex presentation.<ref name=SLCOGa>Sri Lanka College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (SLCOG). (2010). National guidelines: Management of uncomplicated labor. Retrieved from http://www.gfmer.ch/SRH-Course-2010/national-guidelines/pdf/Management-Uncomplicated-Labour-SLCOG.pdf</ref> Once a woman is determined to be in uncomplicated labor, confirmed by vaginal examination and painful contractions, she is transferred to the labor suite of the hospital or maternity home.<ref name=SLCOGa/> While routine enemas are not recommended, SLCOG does emphasize that "efforts must be make to minimize fecal soiling…to overcome the practical difficulties associated with cleaning and maintaining sterility".<ref name=SLCOGap7>Sri Lanka College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (SLCOG). (2010). National guidelines: Management of uncomplicated labor. p.7. Retrieved from http://www.gfmer.ch/SRH-Course-2010/national-guidelines/pdf/Management-Uncomplicated-Labour-SLCOG.pdf</ref> Low risk women are allowed to consume clear fluids during early labor, but must consult an anesthesiologist first.<ref name=SLCOGa/> SLCOG recommends that maternal preference be honored when considering mobility and posture during labor. The organization recommends standing and lateral recumbent positioning to minimize reductions in uterine blood supply and reductions in cardiac output.<ref name=SLCOGa/> Intermittent fetal heart auscultation and observation of vaginal discharge is used to assess the fetal condition.<ref name=SLCOGa/> A [[partogram]] is recommended to facilitate monitoring during labor.<ref name=SLCOGa/> During the second stage of labor, women are encouraged to assume the most comfortable position.<ref name=SLCOGa/> In the second stage of labor fetal heart rate should be assessed every 15 minutes and the fetal heart rate should be assessed after each contraction while bearing down.<ref name=SLCOGa/> Active management of labor with [[oxytocin]] is recommended in the third stage of labor.<ref name=SLCOGa/> Medio-lateral episiotomies are recommended to expedite delivery or prevent perineal injury.<ref name=SLCOGa/> Once the neonate is delivered, the umbilical cord is clamped and cut, controlled cord traction should be applied. It is recommended that the placenta, membranes and umbilical cord are examined for abnormalities after delivery.<ref name=SLCOGa/> After delivery, women should be monitored for complication for two hours in the labor suite.<ref name=SLCOGa/>
===Premature rupture of membranes=== Management of preterm rupture of membranes involves either expectant or active management.<ref name=SLCOGb>Sri Lanka College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (SLCOG).(2010). National guidelines: Management of premature rupture of membranes. Retrieved from http://www.gfmer.ch/SRH-Course-2010/national-guidelines/pdf/Management-PROM-SLCOG.pdf</ref> The classification depends on maturity of the fetus, neonatal facilities available at the place of birth, presence of infection and fetal distress.<ref name=SLCOGb/> Expectant management involves general observation of vital signs and fetal observations, including kick count, presentation, daily electronic fetal monitoring and weekly ultrasound.<ref name=SLCOGb/> Active management beyond 32 weeks gestational age involves administration of corticosteroids, antibiotics and awaiting active labor.<ref name=SLCOGb/> If active labor does not begin within 24 hours, delivery is advised.<ref name=SLCOGb/>
===Pain management in labor=== Generally, Sri Lankan women prefer to give birth without pharmacologic pain management. SLCOG recommends that birthing women be provided with adequate analgesia and the selection of pain relief is determined by institutional protocols, drug availability and patient preference.<ref name=SLCOGa/> Pethidine is the most common drug used for pain management during labor, especially in maternity units where clinicians with advanced medical training and monitoring facilities may not be present.<ref name=Warnakulasuriya>Warnakulasuriya, A. (2010). Obstetric anaesthesia. Sri Lankan Journal of Anaesthesiology, 18(1), 5-9. {{doi|10.4038/slja.v18i1.1553}}</ref> During C-sections, 80% of women receive spinal anesthesia, 15% epidural and 5% general anesthesia.<ref name=Warnakulasuriya/> Non-pharmacologic pain management includes breathing techniques, hot and cold therapy, massage, relaxation techniques, acupuncture, herbalism and hypnosis.<ref name=SLCOGa/> Women often recite ''pirith'' to control breathing during labor. This is a chant performed by monks during pregnancy to ensure safe delivery.<ref name=Paranavitana/>
===Extrinsic factors=== Currently little information exists regarding extrinsic factors that affect birth, such as air, water, food and drink. This is an area for additional research.
==Registration of Birth== Every birth should be registered with the government to obtain a birth certificate which act as the main legal document for a citizen in Sri Lanka. The name of the child (which is given by the parent), details of the mother and the father will be entered in the birth certificate. The birth certificate will be required to obtain the National Identity Card, Passport and many more legal activities. An application form should be obtained from Divisional Secretariat and proceed with the registration.<ref name=dev_sec>{{cite web|title=Obtain a Certified Copy of the Certificate of Birth|url=http://www.gic.gov.lk/gic/index.php?option=com_info&id=355&task=info&lang=en|work=Government Information Center|publisher=GIC|accessdate=25 December 2013}}</ref>
==Birth traditions== The specific date and time of birth are carefully recorded to determine a child's horoscope. The time of birth determines the zodiac sign, and also specific character traits of the child.<ref name=Wanasundera/> The horoscope is significant throughout the lifecycle. It is read by an astrologer at birth, puberty, prior to an examination or new job, when determining if a potential spouse is a good match, or for any other important decision.<ref name="dev_sec"/>
==Postpartum== The postpartum time is not clearly defined; however the puerperium period is defined as the first six weeks in the postpartum period.<ref name=DeSilva1998/> Most women who deliver vaginally spend one night in a health institution, while about 5% return home the day of delivery.<ref name=DeSilva1998/> Women who deliver by C-section typically spend seven nights in the health institution before returning home.<ref name=DeSilva1998/>
Sri Lanka does not have a system to record maternal morbidity, but research suggests maternal morbidity is an area of concern among Sri Lankan mothers. Sri Lankan mothers generally feel that it is natural to experience ill health after childbirth.<ref name=DeSilva1998/> About 90% of women who deliver vaginally and 75% women who deliver by C-section report illness in the puerperium period.<ref name=DeSilva1998/> Examples of these illnesses include excessive bleeding, fever, constipation, breast engorgement, painful urination, backache and abdominal pain.<ref name=DeSilva1998/> Buddhist mothers have the highest incidence of illness while Muslim mothers had the fewest number of poor health outcomes after birth.<ref name=DeSilva1998/>
==Newborn Rites of Passage== Newborn rites of passage vary among ethnic group. Sinhalese, Tamil and Muslim families publicly announce the birth of a child as a gesture of accepting the newborn as a member of the family.<ref name=Mills>Mills, M., Claus, P. and Diamond, S. (Eds.). (2003). South Asian folklore: an encyclopedia: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. New York, NY: Routledge</ref> This may be a casual or grand celebration and often involves food, dancing and singing.<ref name=Mills/>
===Sinhalese=== The exact time of birth is reported to an astrologer who uses the child's horoscope to determine the best letters for the child's name. ''Nam tebima'' is the Sinhalese naming ceremony.<ref name=Mills/> The baby's first outing is typically to a Buddhist temple on a full moon day to receive blessings for a prosperous life. ''Idul kata gema'' is the ceremony to celebrate a baby's first solid food. The ceremony, which takes place either in the family home or in a temple, involves placing dishes of rice boiled with milk, traditional sweets, a banana, a book and a piece of jewelry.<ref name=Wanasundera/> The family observes as the baby is allowed to crawl onto the mat and select an item. If the child chooses the food, he or she will have a healthy appetite for life, if the child chooses the book he or she will have a future in academia, and if the child chooses the jewelry he or she has a promise of fortune and success.<ref name=Wanasundera/>
===Tamil=== The name-giving ceremony, ''Namakarana samskar'', typically takes place 11–41 days after birth.<ref name=Wanasundera/> During this ceremony the baby's father whispers the new name in the infant's right ear. It is typical to celebrate a baby's first consumption of solid food when a child receives his or her first taste of rice. The ceremony typically occurs in a ''kovil'', or Hindu temple.<ref name=Wanasundera/><ref name=Mills/> The meal of boiled rice usually occurs between six and eight months of age.<ref name=Wanasundera/> Other childhood rituals include the ''Chudakarana samskara'', or head-shaving ceremony, which represents purity and removes all remnants of birth pollution. This event marks the end of infancy and the beginning of childhood.<ref name=Mills/> ''Karnavedhna Samskara'' is the name of the ear piercing ceremony that typically takes place either in a temple or at home on the first birthday.<ref name=Mills/>
===Muslim=== Muslim boys are circumcised between the ages of seven days and ten years.<ref name=Mills/> Some communities circumcise males as neonates, while others believe the child should be old enough to understand the significance of the event.<ref name=Mills/> Traditionally, a community member performed circumcisions in the boy's home, though some families now have the procedure done in a medical center.<ref name=Mills/> The celebration includes new clothes for the boy and a special meal prepared for family and friends.<ref name=Mills/>
==Breastfeeding== Breastfeeding is a culturally accepted and encouraged practice in Sri Lanka.<ref name="Agampodi1">Agampodi, S.B. and Agampodi, T.C. (2008). Effect of low cost public health staff training on exclusive breastfeeding. Indian Journal of Pediatrics, 75(11), 1115-1119. {{doi|10.1007/S12098-008-0185-4}}</ref> The rate of breastfeeding initiation is nearly 100%.<ref name=census2003>Department of Census and Statistics, in collaboration with Ministry of Health, Nutrition and Welfare. (2003). Sri Lanka demographic and health survey 2002. Department of Census and Statistics. Sri Lanka: Colombo</ref> In Sri Lanka, public health officials recommend exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of a child's life.<ref name="Agampodi1"/> PHM and medical officers of health provide pre-and post-natal counseling and education to support women in breastfeeding practices.<ref name="Agampodi1"/> In 2000, 54% of women breastfed exclusively for the first four months of life.<ref name=census2003/> Little data exists to determine rate of exclusive breastfeeding at six months of age, but it is believed that very few mothers breastfeed exclusively until their newborn reaches six months of age.<ref name=Agampodi2007>Agampodi, S.B, Agampodi, T.C. and Piyaseeli, U.K. (2007). Breastfeeding practices in a public health field practice area in Sri Lanka: a survival analysis. International Breastfeeding Journal, 2(3). {{doi|10.1186/1746-4358-2-13}}</ref> A study that integrated low cost staff training with job supervision of PHM showed a significant increase in exclusive breastfeeding among mothers in Beruwala, Sri Lanka. The authors believe that six months exclusive breastfeeding is a realistic goal in Sri Lanka and suggest a need to increase training and support for PHM in maternal health care settings.<ref name="Agampodi1"/>
==Circumcision== No information exists on the current rates of male or female circumcision in Sri Lanka. Generally, these are not common procedures among Buddhist and Hindu populations. Male circumcision is practiced among Muslims and is traditionally an occasion for celebration.<ref name=Mills/>
==Contraception== [[Contraception]] is widely used in Sri Lanka, though generally considered a women's issue. The country has a vasectomy rate of 3.7% <ref name=East>East, M. (2002). Contraceptive Sterilization: Global Issues and Trends, EngenderHealth: 17-64.</ref> and many people believe vasectomy inhibits men from performing hard labor.<ref name=DeSilva1992>De Silva, W.I. (1992). Do fertility intentions and behaviour influence sterilization in Sri Lanka? Asia Pacific Population Journal, 7(4), 41-60</ref> In 1979, to increase the use of vasectomy in family planning, the Sri Lankan government began offering monetary incentives to men who agreed to undergo the procedure. Financial payment was the often primary reason for obtaining a vasectomy.<ref name=Dias1988>Dias, L.R. and Dias, M.K. (1988). The motivating factors for vasectomy in Sri Lanka. Journal of Family Welfare, 34(4), 12-22</ref> Many Sri Lankan couples discuss the need for contraception to limit family size and space pregnancies.<ref name=DeSilva2001/> More than two thirds of the married population use some form of contraception.<ref name=East/> Generally, husbands support the use of female contraception.<ref name=DeSilva1992/> In 1993, nearly one fourth of married women were sterilized,<ref name=East/> however the prevalence of female sterilization fell to 17% of ever-married women by 2007.<ref name=Rodrigo>Rodrigo, C. and Muhuthar, R. (2009). Acceptance of ligation and resection of tubes for contraception in Sri Lanka. Journal of Family Planning and Reproductive Health Care, 35, 266 {{doi|10.1783/147118909789587231}}</ref> Women feel it is important to use a method of contraception approved by their husbands.<ref name=DeSilva1992/> This information guides the need to educate both men and women about contraceptive options, use and side effects.<ref name=DeSilva1992/>
==Additional information== *From 1977 to 1978, an outbreak of acute [[polyneuropathy]] affected more than 20 young women. This illness that was restricted to girls attaining menarche and to women after childbirth. The cause of neuropathy could be traced to tri-cresyl phosphate found as a contaminant in gingili oil.<ref name=ScienceDirect>[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T1B-49MDGY5-2DY&_user=10&_coverDate=01%2F10%2F1981&_rdoc=1&_fmt=high&_orig=gateway&_origin=gateway&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_searchStrId=1730511651&_rerunOrigin=scholar.google&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=3aeed3f140afad92f254e44ab67e8560&searchtype=a TOXIC POLYNEUROPATHY DUE TO GINGILI OIL CONTAMINATED WITH TRI-CRESYL PHOSPHATE AFFECTING ADOLESCENT GIRLS IN SRI LANKA] Department of Community Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, [[University of Colombo]]. Retrieved April 25, 2011.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *Pathmanathan, Indra [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=1J1inqctmwQC&oi=fnd&pg=PR11&dq=reproductive+health+in+sri+lanka&ots=LMOevEnDn2&sig=JW5A6FBvMnCqmSBsbwY_UBx4XC8#v=onepage&q=reproductive%20health%20in%20sri%20lanka&f=false Investing in maternal health: learning from Malaysia and Sri Lanka] ''[[Google Books]]'' *Goodburn, Elizabeth [http://www.bmj.com/content/322/7291/917.extract Reducing maternal mortality in the developing world: sector-wide approaches may be the key] ''BMJ Publishing Group Ltd.'' *

The '''Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations''', is a "[[Public-private partnership|public-private coalition]] that aims to derail [[epidemic]]s by speeding up the development of [[vaccine]]s"<ref name=science>{{cite journal|author=John Cohen|date=2 September 2016|title=New vaccine coalition aims to ward off epidemics|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/09/new-vaccine-coalition-aims-ward-epidemics|journal=Science|volume=353|issue=6303}}</ref>
The concept is to develop early phases of vaccines without knowing the details for the form in which the infection will appear, but will still cut down the time to tailor the eventual vaccine to be effective to the epidemic.
Its plan includes preparations for possible outbreaks of [[Lassa fever]], [[Marburg fever]], Middle East Respiratory Syndrome ([[MERS]]), [[Severe acute respiratory syndrome|SARS]], [[Nipah virus]], [[Rift Valley fever]], [[chikungunya]], and others. It is being funded by the [[Wellcome Trust]], the [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]], the [[World Economic Forum]], the governments of [[Norway]], [[Germany]], [[Japan]]<ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-18/ebola-zika-push-drugmakers-to-join-effort-to-avert-pandemics</ref> and [[India]].<ref name=economist>{{cite journal|journal=The Economist|title=Putting shots in the locker|date=3 September 2016|pages=67–68|volume=420|number=9003|url=https://www.economist.com/news/science-and-technology/21706240-how-anticipate-epidemics-putting-shots-locker}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cepi.net|title=Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations}}</ref>
As of April 2018, it has invested $37.5 million in Austria-based Themis Bioscience<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180306005125/en/CEPI-Partners-Themis-Bioscience-Advance-Vaccines-Lassa|title=CEPI Partners with Themis Bioscience to Advance Vaccines Against Lassa Fever and MERS – Press Release|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2018-04-15|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> and $56 million in US-based Inovio Pharmaceuticals, Inc.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2018/04/11/1468470/0/en/Inovio-Awarded-up-to-56-Million-from-CEPI-to-Advance-DNA-Vaccines-Against-Lassa-Fever-and-MERS.html|title=Inovio Awarded up to $56 Million from CEPI to Advance DNA Vaccines Against Lassa Fever and MERS – Press Release|last=|first=|date=|work=GlobeNewswire News Room|access-date=2018-04-15|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> to develop vaccine candidates against Lassa fever and MERS.
They published a study in [[the Lancet]] in 2018 which estimated the costs of developing vaccines for diseases that could escalate into global humanitarian crises. They focused on 11 diseases which cause relatively few deaths at present and primarily strike the poor. They estimated that it would cost between $2.8 billion and $3.7 billion to develop at least one vaccine for each of them. This should be set against the potential cost of an outbreak. The 2003 SARS outbreak in East Asia cost $54 billion.<ref>{{cite news |title=Scientists have estimated the cost of stopping 11 diseases that could kill millions in a pandemic |url=https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2018/10/22/17999676/vaccine-ebola-pandemic-disease-zika-epidemic-sars?platform=hootsuite |accessdate=2 December 2018 |publisher=Vox |date=22 October 2018}}</ref>

The '''Corpulence Index''' ('''CI''') or '''Ponderal Index''' ('''PI''') is a measure of leanness (corpulence) of a person''Foods and Nutrition Encyclopedia'', Audrey H. Ensminger, Marion Eugene Ensminger. p. 1645 calculated as a relationship between mass and height.[http://oregonstate.edu/instruct/exss323/Intro_Lab/PI.HTM EXSS 323: LAB 1 - BIOMECHANICS TOOLS: Computers, Algebra and Trig] Oregon State University It was first proposed in 1921 as the "Corpulence measure" by Swiss physician Fritz Rohrer{{cite journal|title=Der Index der Körperfülle als Maß des Ernährungszustandes|author=F. Rohrer|journal=Münchner Med. Wschr|volume=68|year=1921|pages=580–582}} and hence is also known as '''Rohrer's Index'''.http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-the-ponderal-index.htm It is similar to the [[body mass index]], but the mass is normalized with the third power of body height rather than the second power. :\mathrm{CI} = \frac{mass}{height^3} with mass in kilograms and height in meters, giving a measure with the same [[Dimensional analysis|dimensions]] as [[density]]. The corpulence index yields valid results even for very short and very tall persons.Lawrence F. Ditmier: ''New Developments in Obesity Research''. Nova Science Publishers, Hauppauge, New York 2006, {{ISBN|1-60021-296-4}}{{page needed|date=April 2012}} Because of this property, it is most commonly used in [[pediatrics]].{{cite journal |doi=10.1079/PNS19800005 |title=Size at birth and growth in the first year of life of babies who are overweight and underweight at birth |year=1980 |last1=Davies |first1=D. P. |journal=Proceedings of the Nutrition Society |volume=39 |pages=25–33 |pmid=6988835 |issue=1}}[http://www.unsystem.org/scn/archives/npp19/ch06.htm ACC/SCN NUTRITION POLICY PAPER No. 19 - Glossary] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070820153440/http://www.unsystem.org/scn/archives/npp19/ch06.htm |date=2007-08-20 }} by Lindsay H. Allen and Stuart R. Gillespie (For a baby, one can take [[crown-heel length]] for the height.{{cite journal|last1=Fayyaz|first1=Jabeen|title=Ponderal Index|journal=Journal of Pakistan Medical Association|date=June 2005|url=http://www.jpma.org.pk/full_article_text.php?article_id=750}}) The normal values for infants are about twice as high as for adults, which is the result of their relatively short legs.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} It does not need to be adjusted for age after adolescence.{{Cite journal|url = http://journals.lww.com/cjsportsmed/Citation/2015/03000/American_Medical_Society_for_Sports_Medicine_2015.18.aspx|title = Evaluating the Performance of 4 Indices in Determining Adiposity|last = Babar|first = Sultan|date = March 2015|journal = Clinical Journal of Sport Medicine|doi = |pmid = |access-date = August 2015|publisher = Lippincott Williams & Wilkins) |volume=25|number=2|edition = |page = 183}} It has also been shown to have a lower false positive rate in athletes.{{Cite journal|url = http://journals.lww.com/cjsportsmed/Fulltext/2016/03000/AMSSM_Research_Abstract_Oral_Poster_Presentations.17.aspx|title = The Use of Adiposity Indices for Wide Receivers From 2015 NFL Combine|last = Babar|first = Sultan|date = March 2016|journal = Clinical Journal of Sport Medicine|doi = |pmid = |access-date = April 2016|volume=26|number=2|publisher = Lippincott Williams & Wilkins) 2|edition = |page = e23}} The corpulence index is variously defined (the first definition should be preferred due to the use of [[International System of Units|SI-units]] ''kg'' and ''m'') as follows: {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=2 | Formula ! rowspan=2 | Units for mass
(body weight) ! rowspan=2 | Units for height
(or length) ! colspan=2 | Values considered normal or typical |- ! for a 12-month-old infant ! beyond infancy |- | \text{CI}=\frac{mass}{height^3} | kilograms | metres | 24 | 12 |- | \text{CI}=1000\frac{mass}{height^3} | grams | centimetres | colspan=2 | (same values as above) |- | \text{CI}=1000\times\frac{\sqrt[3]{mass}}{height} | kilograms | centimetres | colspan=2 | Between 20 and 25 http://oregonstate.edu/instruct/exss323/Intro_Lab/PI.HTM |- | \text{CI}=\frac{height}{\sqrt[3]{mass}}https://captaincalculator.com/health/weight/ponderal-index-calculator/ | pounds | inches |colspan=2 | 12.49 to 13.92 |} ==Significance== * It plays a role in assessing whether the [[intrauterine growth restriction]] of a child is symmetrical or asymmetrical.{{cite journal|last1=Khoury|first1=MJ|last2=Berg|first2=CJ|last3=Calle|first3=EE|title=The ponderal index in term newborn siblings.|journal=American Journal of Epidemiology|date=September 1990|volume=132|issue=3|pages=576–83|pmid=2389761|url=http://aje.oxfordjournals.org/content/132/3/576}} * CI has been shown to have higher sensitivity, specificity, as well as both [[positive and negative predictive values]] than [[body mass index]]. ==See also== * [[Body adiposity index]] * [[Body mass index]] * [[Waist-to-height ratio]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.health-calc.com/body-composition/ponderal-index Online Ponderal Index Calculator], which uses the first definition. * [http://www.nordic-walking-ratgeber.de/ponderal-index-rechner.php Ponderal Index Calculator], which uses metric values. (German site) * [https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.sultanbabar.corpulenceindex&hl=en Android App for Corpulence Index] * [https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/corpulence-index/id946169331?mt=8 Apple app for Corpulence Index] [[Category:Medical terminology]] [[Category:Body shape]] [[Category:Classification of obesity]] [[Category:Human weight]] [[Category:Pediatrics]]
